sections.desc: A Test Bed for Storytelling & Dialogue Through Television

sub_sections.title: POV Debuts on PBS
sub_sections.desc: At the 1986 U.S. Film Festival (later The Sundance Film Festival), Marc Weiss meets FRONTLINE's David Fanning at a festival panel and is convinced there is a future for bold, independent, point-of-view documentary storytelling on television. Soon after, he is organizing meetings with the producers and public TV representatives who were at odds in the 1980s but who would collaborate and form the editorial core of a new PBS documentary series — POV.

sub_sections.quote: When POV broadcast its first season, the Internet was just emerging from the rarefied world of university research and defense communications. Cable was new... Faxes were a novelty. Email, like the CD-ROM, was far in the future. DVD was just a glimmer in some corporate eye.

sub_sections.title: The Birth of the Web
sub_sections.desc: Between 1989 and 1991, Tim Berners-Lee invents Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) and the World Wide Web.

sub_sections.title: You Saw Them On POV First
sub_sections.desc: Fahrenheit 9/11 director Michael Moore (Roger & Me and Pets or Meat: The Return to Flint, 1992), The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara director Errol Morris (Gates of Heaven, 1988), Ghost World director Terry Zwigoff (Louie Bluie, 1988)

sub_sections.title: User-Generated Video: "Talking Back"
sub_sections.desc:
In 1993, POV started inviting viewers to record video comments to be aired on television in a segment initially called "Talking Back: Video Letters to P.O.V." The videos — sometimes critical, sometimes touching, sometimes funny — became a hallmark of POV's early seasons and another means for new views to be heard on national television.

These clips have not been seen since the original September 12, 1993, broadcast.

sub_sections.quote: This film is going to be on TV. How can it enhance what you are doing?
sub_sections.by_who: Ellen Schneider (Executive Producer, 1993-1994) to a group of community leaders, policymakers and people from AIDS organizations she convened for a screening of Silverlake Life in 1993.

sub_sections.title: A First Second Screen: POV Online
sub_sections.desc: POV launched an unprecedented experiment in the spring of 1994 — POV Online — to enable discourse about its programs over increasingly networked computers. POV hosted chat rooms with filmmakers, timed to national broadcasts, on the most popular online service of the time, America Online (AOL). The first chat included Ross McElwee (known for his Sundance Grand Jury Prize-winning Sherman's March). In 1995, the new POV Interactive department created pov.org, the first web site developed for a public TV series.

sub_sections.quote: Finally, the technology is available to start a real dialogue with TV.
sub_sections.by_who: Founder Marc Weiss in an early letter to POV's Online Advisory Group

sub_sections.title: By the Numbers
sub_sections.desc: In the winter of 1994, 5,000,000 Americans had access to the Internet and there were about 10,000 websites.

sub_sections.title: More User-Generated Video: "Two-Way TV"
sub_sections.desc:
Two-Way TV was a "user-generated" program that POV aired on November 17, 1995, after receiving 1,000 responses — many of which were emails — to Leona's Sister Gerri, about a woman dead after a botched illegal abortion. POV founder Marc Weiss says the program proves "discussion of public issues can be much more than warring sound-bites."
Available online for the first time since its original broadcast.

sub_sections.title: High Impact Television
sub_sections.desc: POV formalized and shared its methodology for national engagement via pre-existing community networks and media in 1995, calling it High Impact Television. It was directly inspired by the campaigns of Silverlake Life in 1993 and The Heart of the Matter, the first film to look at the AIDS crisis as a women's issue, in 1994.

sub_sections.title: The First Multimedia Companion Site
sub_sections.desc:
POV Interactive created its first broadcast companion site in 1996, for Just For The Ride, a film by Amanda Micheli about two inspiring rodeo cowgirls. The site included audio and video interviews, a bucking bronco game and forums about cowgirl fashion.
Explore the newly recovered website.

sub_sections.title: Re: Vietnam
sub_sections.desc: The "Re: Vietnam" site (stories.org) elicited stories from viewers — one of the first broadcast-related websites to invite user-generated content — not about their experiences of the war itself but rather how it had shaped who they had become. The site included a collection of multimedia submitted to POV by veterans and a by-invitation listserv that gathered a diverse group for a more focused dialogue. Re: Vietnam was named one of USA Today's best websites of the year.

sub_sections.title: Television Race Initiative
sub_sections.desc: The success of High Impact Television inspires the multi-year Television Race Initiative, which uses POV documentaries to facilitate problem-solving activities and community dialogue about race and culture.
In 1997, AOL launched Instant Messenger (a few months after Mirabilis' ICQ). Both applications allowed users to communicate online in real time.

sub_sections.title: POV Salon
sub_sections.desc: POV Salon, a continuation of the online experiment, acted like a book club for documentaries, facilitating opinionated conversation in small online groups around POV films and the issues they raised.

The software behind POV Salon was created by Brian Clark, who was at the same time co-creating one of the first "transmedia" film projects, a website for the pseudo-documentary horror film, The Blair Witch Project

sub_sections.title: Film Campaigns
sub_sections.desc: Under new Executive Director Cara Mertes, POV produces full campaigns for all of its films, not the just selections each season. Often contending with a tight deadlines — the time from acquisition to broadcast may be a few months — POV begins creating pre-licensed film clips for educators (a first for public television), downloadable lesson plans, "delve deeper" resources and interactive features.

sub_sections.title: You Saw Them On POV First
sub_sections.desc: Edward Snowden interviewer Laura Poitras (Flag Wars, 2003; a POV Diverse Voices Project grantee for emerging filmmakers), double-Oscar nominee Marshall Curry (Street Fight, 2005)

sub_sections.quote: I felt the time was right culturally to expand [POV] in every way, from production to distribution, education and outreach, and interactively. Not just to reach audience, but to engage existing audiences and endeavor to create new ones.

sub_sections.title: By the Numbers
sub_sections.desc: In 2002, for the first time, more than half of Americans now had access to the Internet.

sub_sections.title: POV Borders
sub_sections.desc: POV launches PBS's first web-only original series, POV Borders: Migration, in 2002, as a showcase for interactive storytelling. It pioneers a new form of public dialogue — one in which user interaction with creatively documented individual and community stories becomes the primary language for exploring how we live our lives today. Two chapters followed: Environment (2004), named one of Time's best websites of the year and winner of a Webby Award, and American ID (2006), which examines perceptions of the United States.

sub_sections.title: Two Towns of Jasper
sub_sections.desc: In 2003, a ground-breaking partnership between multiple broadcasters — PBS, ABC and Oprah — also harnesssed the power of the web. On January 22, POV aired Two Towns of Jasper, a film by two filmmakers, one white and one black, about a modern-day lynching in Texas. Web TV viewers interacted with each other and retrieved a wealth of context in real time. The previous day, the filmmakers were guests on Oprah. The following day, Ted Koppel (Nightline) hosted a town hall in Jasper using data from the live screening. Over three nights, 20 million people experienced the power of independent media.

sub_sections.title: The Webby Awards
sub_sections.desc: POV Interactive is nominated for its sixth Webby Award in six years in 2009, competing against cable networks and Hollywood film sites for awards that recognize online excellence.

sub_sections.title: Water is the new oil
sub_sections.desc: POV won a Webby Award for the Environment chapter of POV Borders, but because a ceremony was not held in 2004, no five-word acceptance speeches were heard. This would have been POV's.

sub_sections.title: For Filmmakers
sub_sections.desc: Building on a tradition of supporting filmmakers dating back to its earliest days, POV re-launches a behind-the-scenes subsite as For Filmmakers, a resource for producing both traditional and new-format documentaries. The subsite connects to 25 years of filmmaker interviews and POV's Documentary Blog, which establishes itself as a leading hub for conversation, with spokes on social media sites such as Facebook and Twitter.

sub_sections.title: Creative Collaboration at POV Hackathon
sub_sections.desc: The POV Hackathon lab series marks the new ways media makers are approaching nonfiction. Documentaries are no longer informed by Flaherty, Grierson or the Drew Associates, but also Jobs, Ogilvy and Zuckerberg — which is to say that software developers, entrepreneurs and advertisers are providing insights into how independent nonfiction media can thrive in a digitally connected world.

sub_sections.by_who: Adnaan Wasey, Executive Producer, POV Digital (2012-present)
sub_sections.quote: As we've evolved from chat rooms to multimedia websites to social media, our digital philosophy hasn't changed. We are continuing to leverage technology to explore how to tell stories, how to engage audiences and how to support communities connected to those stories.

sub_sections.title: POV Hackathon: Living Los Sures
sub_sections.desc: A collaboratively produced interactive documentary that explores the legacy of urban poverty on the increasingly trendy south side of Brooklyn's Williamsburg neighborhood.

sub_sections.title: POV Hackathon: Empire
sub_sections.desc: Empire unearths the contemporary aftershocks of the world's first brush with global capitalism through a broad range of storytelling techniques — including nonfiction filmmaking, multi-channel video projection, and experience design.

sub_sections.title: POV Hackathon: Unknown Spring
sub_sections.desc: A chronicle of and testament to the Japanese people's resilience and humanity in the face of unspeakable odds.

sub_sections.title: POV Hackathon: The Whiteness Project
sub_sections.desc: The Whiteness Project is a cross-platform investigation by Whitney Dow, one of the two directors of Two Towns of Jasper, into how white Americans experience their ethnicity.

sub_sections.title: POV Hackathon: Portraits of the Enemies
sub_sections.desc: A web-based documentary that juxtaposes portraits of enemy fighters face-to-face by international photojournalist Karim Ben Khelifa.

sub_sections.title: The Reportero Challenge
sub_sections.desc: POV Borders segment producer Bernardo Ruiz returned to POV 10 years later as the director of his own film. The 2013 documentary Reportero, about the plight of journalists in Mexico, also spawned a POV game, The Reportero Challenge. Do you have what it takes to be a Mexican newspaper editor? Take the challenge!

sub_sections.by_who: Simon Kilmurry, Executive Director & Executive Producer (2006-present)
sub_sections.quote: [POV] remains remarkably true to its founding mission, which is to support independent documentary makers, to help them find a space within culture at large, and to work with audiences and communities on how these films illuminate larger issues in a more granular way.
